quiz.title: Chemistry: Unit 6 Quiz 10
quiz.subtitle: 6.10: Comparing Properties: Ionic and Covalent Compounds
quiz.subject: Chemistry

questions.question: Which of the following generally has the highest melting point?
questions.explanation: The electrostatic forces in an ionic crystal lattice are much stronger than the intermolecular forces (like London dispersion or dipole-dipole) found in covalent molecular substances.

questions.question: Covalent molecular compounds are often gases or liquids at room temperature because:
options: Their intermolecular forces are relatively weak compared to ionic bonds.
They are only made of metal atoms.
They are always heavier than ionic compounds.
questions.explanation: Because molecules are discrete units held together by weak forces (Van der Waals), they require less energy to overcome these attractions and change phase.

questions.question: Which type of compound is most likely to be a good conductor of electricity when dissolved in water?
questions.explanation: Ionic compounds dissociate into free-moving ions in solution, which can carry an electrical current.

questions.question: How do the 'building blocks' of ionic and covalent compounds differ?
options: Ionic compounds consist of a lattice of ions; covalent compounds consist of discrete molecules.
Ionic compounds consist of molecules; covalent compounds consist of ions.
Ionic compounds are made of only nonmetals; covalent compounds are made of metals.
There is no difference in their fundamental building blocks.
questions.explanation: Ionic substances form repeating 3D structures (formula units), while covalent substances exist as individual, independent groups of atoms (molecules).

questions.question: Which type of compound generally has a higher 'volatility' (evaporates easily)?
questions.explanation: Weak intermolecular forces in covalent compounds mean that molecules can easily escape from the liquid phase into the gas phase.

questions.question: A substance that is a soft solid, has a low melting point, and does not conduct electricity when melted is most likely:
questions.explanation: These are characteristic properties of molecular solids like wax or sugar.

questions.question: Bonding in a molecule like $HCl$ is __________; the force between two $HCl$ molecules is __________.
questions.explanation: Bonds within a molecule (intra-) are strong covalent bonds; forces between separate molecules (inter-) are weaker dipole-dipole forces.

questions.question: Which of these is a 'network covalent' solid, which behaves differently than most molecular compounds by having a very high melting point?
questions.explanation: Network solids like diamond or quartz involve a continuous web of covalent bonds throughout the entire structure, making them incredibly hard and heat-resistant.

questions.question: When comparing $NaCl$ (ionic) and $H_{2}O$ (covalent), which statement is true?
options: $NaCl$ has a much higher boiling point than $H_{2}O$.
$H_{2}O$ is a solid at room temperature while $NaCl$ is a gas.
Both substances are held together by London dispersion forces only.
questions.explanation: Ionic $NaCl$ boils at $1413\text{°C}$, while molecular $H_{2}O$ boils at $100\text{°C}$.

questions.question: Why are most ionic compounds brittle, while many covalent molecular solids are soft?
options: Repulsion between like-charged ions shatters the lattice; weak intermolecular forces allow molecular solids to be easily displaced.
Ionic bonds are weaker than covalent bonds.
Ionic compounds contain air pockets that make them snap.
questions.explanation: The rigid lattice of ions cannot easily shift without breaking, whereas molecules are only loosely held to their neighbors.
